He was the one that no doubt went with her to Lexâ€™sÂ court hearings. He was the one that probably helped her work through her childhood trauma.Â  Jack was important to Lenaâ€™s character. He had a huge role in her life as her friend and as more. Iâ€™m not saying I think she loved him

He and Kara couldâ€™ve bonded over their shared adoration of Lena. They couldâ€™ve been friends too. Jack and James couldâ€™ve bonded over shared experiences as men of color and how that affected their daily lives and business personas.Â  Jack Spheer was a genius

After Rhea (Teri Hatcher) effectively tricked Lena (Katie McGrath) into creating a portal that would allow the surviving Daxamite race to come to Earth â€” err
column2: New Daxam â€” Kara (Melissa Benoist) will have to turn to some unlikely allies to combat this new threat
column3: not least of which is Cadmus leader Lillian Luthor (Brenda Strong). But just because they are aligned now doesnâ€™t mean Cadmus has stopped hating aliens. In fact

column6: â€ Kreisberg continues. â€œWe saved a bunch of money to pay for more visual effects and actually added another day to the schedule so we could make it as big as possible
column7: and yet it also has multiple get-your-Kleenex scenes. Weâ€™re really excited about it. Weâ€™re all blown away.â€ With villains abound

sapphics 158981385537 "2017-03-29 23:34:22 GMT" http://sapphics.tumblr.com/post/158981385537/supergirl-has-a-mon-el-problem "lexaclarke: Chris Wood is an insanely charismatic actor. He has the uncanny ability to take a throwaway line and turn it into a delightful one-liner. And though Iâ€™m not sure he has the emotional range of Melissa Benoist
column4: if there were an Oscar for charisma
column5: he would rightly be in the running for it. But Chris Woodâ€™s inherent likability is separate from a question Iâ€™ve been asking myself about this season of Supergirl: Is Mon-El a good character? Iâ€™ve been on the fence for a while
column7: â€ Iâ€™ve finally decided that the answer is no.Or rather
column8: Mon-El is not a character worthy of as much time as Supergirl has given him this season. Supergirl has always been an ensemble series that lets different characters take prominence in different episodes
column9: but Mon-El has gotten far more than his fair share of screentime this season. And rather than use him as a lens through which to explore Kara (a frequent role of a superhero love interest)
column10: the writers just like to focus on Mon-El full stop
column11: especially in episodes like â€œMr. & Mrs. Mxyzptlkâ€ and â€œHomecoming.â€ Heâ€™s not only filled the hole left by Cat Grant
column12: but sometimes pushed into the narrative place of James
column15: at times it feels like Mon-El is a co-lead of the series.I donâ€™t think the rise of Mon-El comes from a malicious place in the writerâ€™s room
column16: although it does have the unfortunate side effect of centering a white male lead in a show that used to focus on women and feature an interracial relationship. If I had to make a guess as to why Mon-El has become such a focus
column17: I would wager that after spending a whole season writing for their main ensemble
column18: crafting stories for a new character is a much easier source of creativity for the writers. And
column20: the charm Wood can bring to an episode no doubt makes the writers want to favor him as well. But his exaggerated importance this season has thrown off Supergirlâ€™s equilibrium." False link
